steps: I often manage to complete a task well, even if at first I thought I wouldn't succeed
I can give the impression that I am more competent than I really am
I feel terrified when someone evaluates my work
When people praise me for my achievements, I fear that I won't live up to their expectations of me in the future
Sometimes I think I got this job or achieved success because I was in the right place at the right time
I fear that people who are important to me will find out that I am not as capable as they think
I tend to remember my failures more than my successes
I rarely complete a project or task as well as I would like
Sometimes I feel that success in my life or work is the result of a mistake
I find it difficult to accept compliments or praise regarding my intellect and achievements
At times, I feel that my success is due to luck
I am disappointed with my achievements at the moment and think that I should have achieved much more
Sometimes I fear that others will discover how much knowledge or ability I really lack
I often fear that I will fail a new task or assignment, even if I generally perform similar tasks well
When I succeed in something and receive recognition for my achievements, I have doubts that I can repeat this success
If I receive a lot of praise and recognition for what I have achieved, I tend to downplay the importance of my accomplishments
I often compare my abilities to those of the people around me and think that they are smarter than me
I often worry that I will not be able to cope with a project or exam, even if those around me are confident in my abilities
If I am expecting a promotion or recognition, I hesitate to tell others until it is certain
I feel bad if I am not the 'best' in situations that imply achievements

0.text: People with impostor syndrome often underestimate their abilities and attribute their successes to external factors such as luck or the help of others, instead of recognizing their own skills and efforts.
0.fact: Emma Watson, a well-known actress and activist, has openly spoken about her feelings of impostorism. Despite her successes in film and public life, she often doubted her abilities and feared that people would discover her 'inadequacy'.

1.text: The feeling that you are giving the impression of being more competent than you believe yourself to be is a characteristic sign of impostor syndrome. People with this syndrome often feel that their successes are undeserved and fear being exposed.
1.fact: According to the American Psychological Association, about 25% of office workers feel less competent than their colleagues perceive them to be.

2.text: The fear of evaluation of one's work is a common symptom of impostor syndrome. People with this syndrome often fear that their work will not be good enough.
2.fact: Fear of evaluation can lead to procrastination and avoidance of tasks that require review and feedback. This reinforces feelings of insecurity and self-criticism.

3.text: Accepting praise and recognizing your achievements are important steps in overcoming impostor syndrome. Psychologists recommend regularly reminding yourself of your successes and merits, and learning to accept compliments without internal resistance.
3.fact: In a survey conducted among students of prestigious universities, about 60% admitted that they felt less confident in their abilities after receiving positive evaluations or praise.

4.text: Acknowledging your skills and hard work is an important step in overcoming impostor syndrome. People who regularly analyze and recognize their successes are less likely to experience feelings of impostorism.
4.fact: Tina Fey, a well-known comedian and writer, has repeatedly mentioned her feelings of impostorism. She often thought that her successes in comedy and television were coincidental. In her book 'Bossypants', she shares her doubts and fears, showing that even the most successful people can feel out of place.

5.text: Psychotherapy, especially cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), helps people recognize and change their negative thoughts and beliefs. CBT helps develop a more realistic perception of one's abilities and achievements.
5.fact: Tom Hanks, a famous actor and two-time Oscar winner, has openly spoken about his fear of being exposed. He admitted that he often feels out of place and fears that people will realize that he is not as talented as they think.

6.text: People with impostor syndrome often focus on their failures, ignoring or downplaying their successes. This phenomenon is associated with cognitive distortions such as the negative filter and discounting the positive.
6.fact: Michelle Obama, former First Lady of the United States, has spoken about her feelings of impostorism and tendency to focus on failures. In her autobiography 'Becoming', she shares how she had to fight the feeling that her successes were accidental and undeserved, and how she learned to recognize and appreciate her achievements.

7.text: Feeling dissatisfied with the results of your work and striving for perfection are common symptoms of impostor syndrome. People with this syndrome often set unrealistically high standards for themselves, leading to a constant feeling that their work is not good enough.
7.fact: Striving for perfection can reinforce feelings of impostorism. People who constantly strive for the ideal often experience anxiety and fear of failure, which hinders the recognition of their achievements.

8.text: This cognitive distortion is called the 'illusion of randomness' and is associated with low self-esteem and high levels of self-criticism. People with this distortion often underestimate their abilities and believe that their successes are undeserved.
8.fact: Albert Einstein, one of the greatest scientists of all time, often spoke about his feelings of impostorism. Despite his outstanding achievements in science, he believed that his successes were coincidental and the result of luck. Einstein said, 'I feel a sense of injustice towards those who overestimate my abilities and achievements.'

9.text: Negative thoughts and the inner critic can undermine the ability to accept positive feedback. People with impostor syndrome often interpret compliments as exaggerated or undeserved, which prevents the recognition of their own successes.
9.fact: According to surveys, about 60% of women and 40% of men report that they find it difficult to accept compliments in a professional environment because they feel undeserving.

10.text: People with impostor syndrome often feel that their successes are due to luck or coincidence rather than their own abilities. This can lead to a constant sense of anxiety and fear of being exposed.
10.fact: External success and recognition do not always eliminate feelings of impostorism. Even people who have achieved great heights in their professions can continue to feel like 'frauds'.

11.text: Negative thoughts and the inner critic can undermine the ability to accept positive feedback. People with impostor syndrome often interpret compliments as exaggerated or undeserved, which prevents the recognition of their own successes.
11.fact: According to surveys, about 60% of women and 40% of men report that they find it difficult to accept compliments in a professional environment because they feel undeserving.

12.text: People with impostor syndrome often possess high levels of intelligence and competence, but their inner beliefs do not align with reality. They may underestimate their abilities and achievements, leading to a constant sense of anxiety.
12.fact: Practicing positive self-talk and self-acceptance can help reduce the fear of exposure. Psychotherapists recommend recording your successes and recognitions to remind yourself of your competence.

13.text: The fear of failure, even when successfully completing similar tasks in the past, is a characteristic manifestation of impostor syndrome. This fear can limit professional growth and personal development, as the person avoids new challenges and opportunities.
13.fact: The fear of failure is often associated with perfectionism and high expectations. People with impostor syndrome may set unrealistically high standards for themselves, which intensifies their fear of failure.

14.text: Doubts about the ability to repeat success, despite recognition, can arise from cognitive distortions such as 'impostor syndrome' and the 'superiority paradox'. People experiencing these distortions tend to downplay their successes and consider them random.
14.fact: These doubts can be related to the Dunning-Kruger effect, where highly skilled people underestimate their abilities, while less competent people overestimate their skills. People with impostor syndrome often belong to the first group.

15.text: The tendency to devalue one's achievements, despite praise and recognition, is associated with a cognitive distortion known as 'disqualification of the positive'. People with this distortion tend to ignore or downplay the significance of their successes and achievements.
15.fact: Psychologists recommend practicing mindful acknowledgment of one's successes and achievements. This can be done by keeping a gratitude journal where positive moments and achievements are recorded, or by discussing one's successes with trusted individuals.

16.text: Constantly comparing oneself to others can lead to a 'deficit effect', where a person focuses on their weaknesses and underestimates their strengths and achievements.
16.fact: People suffering from impostor syndrome often forget that those around them may also experience similar doubts and insecurities. Realizing this fact can help reduce feelings of loneliness and inadequacy.

17.text: Anxiety about tasks is often associated with perfectionism and fear of failure. People with impostor syndrome may set unrealistically high standards for themselves, which increases their anxiety.
17.fact: Studies show that positive reinforcement and support from others can significantly reduce anxiety levels and boost self-confidence. Developing self-support and mindfulness skills also helps in coping with impostor syndrome.

18.text: Surveys among professionals show that about 55% of respondents delay sharing their successes, fearing that they may not occur or be perceived negatively.
18.fact: Sheryl Sandberg, COO of Facebook and author of the book 'Lean In', admitted that she often felt afraid to share her successes and achievements. She feared that if she mentioned them prematurely, she might not meet expectations or face criticism.

19.text: The drive to be the best can lead to burnout and chronic stress. People experiencing impostor syndrome often work harder and longer to meet their high standards, which negatively impacts their mental and physical health.
19.fact: Serena Williams, one of the most successful tennis players of all time, spoke about her drive to be the best and her feelings of impostorism. Despite her numerous victories and achievements, she often felt the pressure to always be at the top and the fear of not meeting expectations.

range.extreme: Extremely pronounced signs of impostor syndrome

normal.text: It seems that the concept of 'impostor syndrome' is something from the realm of fantasy for you. You don't waste time on useless comparisons with others, you don't fear failure, and you are always ready to prove your competence again. Your drive for success often brings you well-deserved results. You are not one to torment yourself over having done too little or worry that someone might uncover your weaknesses and gaps in knowledge. You are confident in yourself and your abilities, and this helps you move forward.
normal.title: Confidence in one's own worth

light.text: You are able to assess yourself and your achievements objectively. Yes, sometimes it is difficult for you to accept praise, enjoy success, and not compare yourself to others – and that is completely normal. But you skillfully handle troubling thoughts, can stop and look at your work objectively, assessing the efforts put in, strengths, and weaknesses. You don't blame yourself for mistakes because you understand that they are an integral part of the path to growth.
light.title: Mild signs of impostor syndrome

severe.text: You scored high on the impostor syndrome scale, indicating its significant impact on your ability to work effectively, assert yourself, and achieve goals. In your case, the 'perfectionist syndrome', striving for perfection even with a fever of 38°C, and the constant fear of being exposed as incompetent are overshadowed by deeper anxieties. This inner critic constantly undermines your confidence and prevents you from fully realizing your potential.
severe.title: Severe signs of impostor syndrome

extreme.text: You have reached a critical point on the impostor syndrome scale, indicating its enormous impact on your life. Your constant striving for perfection is accompanied by an exhausting fear of being exposed as a 'fraud'. Every achievement seems accidental, and every compliment causes anxiety rather than joy. You constantly feel that you don't deserve your success and that soon everyone will realize how incompetent you really are. This deep inner conflict exhausts you, hindering both personal and professional growth, creating barriers to true self-expression and self-realization.
extreme.title: Extremely pronounced signs of impostor syndrome

text: Have you ever felt that your success is just a lucky coincidence? That your achievements are not the result of your efforts but mere luck?
Impostor syndrome is a psychological issue that makes us doubt our own competence and merits, despite all evidence to the contrary.
This test will help you determine how strongly impostor syndrome affects your life.
